pros: Management are supportive, team are great and we all support each other with work etc. Benefits and pay is great. Love our values and what we do.
cons: There are no cons to working here.

job_title: Head Veterinary Nurse in London, England
pros: If you’re clinical you will like enjoy the variation in work and the team you work with. That’s sadly about it.
cons: This organisation is now absolutely full of “middle managements” who contribute nothing but are comfortable working from home attending zoom meetings everyday, very much a meeting about a meeting culture. Clinical staff are paid poorly and the HR team hide behind the guise of “it’s a charity” while the entire back office team are collecting £50000-70000 per annum for doing a menial, basic, non essential (non needed) job.

pros: The cause is amazing and the vet staff do incredible work in often challenging conditions. Has the potential to be an amazing charity
cons: Working here is CHAOTIC, it felt like a constant rollercoaster, with annual ‘restructures’ IE redundancies across all departments. Each new structure had a chance to bed in. The fundraising/marketing director role is a revolving door, no doubt to the volatility from long-standing members of SMT. There is no professional development whatsoever. Pay rises are impossible to obtain even after consistently over performing, your only reward will be having more work load from under performing colleagues stacked onto you. EDI isn’t existent, unless you’re white and middle class you’re going to have a tough time here having your voice heard. There is a culture of bullying which is not only allowed to go on but comes from the DG down. Pay below the market rate for roles, and will continue to scratch their head as to why so many people leave.

job_title: Area Veterinary Manager in Newcastle upon Tyne, England

cons: Retention of some key employees disjointed communications sometimes.

The forum is a great platform for the employee voice to be heard and ideas are genuinely listened to/implemented. Working for the organisation is like having a second family. Lots of support and understanding across the board. Great flexible working opportunities and benefits.
cons: Growth and development in some of the support roles. Reason for me leaving.

review_title: A great cause, but exiting staff not treated well
pros: Supporting with the care for animals is so important and a highly rewarding part of the job. The people are still pleasant to work with and it’s a nice working environment.
cons: The way PDSA handled their redundancy process during covid was incredibly poor. I understand that the treatment of animals became a priority which is right, but staff were cut off without even a thank you. After being on furlough for 7 months I just received a p45 with no thank you for my service or empathy on what a difficult year it had been. A very disappointing exit of what was my dream job and an organisation I used to highly value.

review_title: Do not accept a job at this failing charity
pros: Treat any job at PDSA as a temporary position and you might find it worthwhile.
cons:
There are three PDSAs really:

Veterinary
Retail
Head Office.

You'll notice most of the good reviews on Glassdoor are from staff and volunteers from the Veterinary or Retail divisions. I can't comment on those areas since they seem to be culturally and operationally different to the Head Office operations, of which I couldn't be more scathing.

I worked there for six years and every year without fail there would be a huge restructure with entire departments put at risk of redundancy. Marketing, Finance, Marketing again, Retail, Marketing again, Legacies, IT possibly. Can't remember all of them. But the effect of seeing your colleagues fearing for their jobs constantly, then new blood coming in only to be turfed out 18 months later was soul-destroying. I constantly felt the pressure of the axe and would take that anxiety home where I'd worry about how I'd keep my family fed and homed if the Directors decided on a whim to target my department next.

The anxiety got to a point for me where I took a temporary position in the public sector just to escape the uncertainty. This was an excellent decision since I must have become somewhat institutionalised. It was only upon leaving that I realised what a dysfunctional place PDSA was and how normal workplaces with normal leaderships don't stoke this culture of fear and instability. 

Since leaving, the restructures have continued. Eventually the axe fell on my former department, and whatever goal the leadership is aiming for has continued to evade them. During COVID-19, the ruthless, unethical, self-serving leadership decided it was another great opportunity for yet another massive restructure. So they turfed out another cohort of long-serving staff into a bleak economy. Former colleagues who gave PDSA their best years, continually delivering excellent results just thrown under the bus for another throw of the dice by the leadership, who then went on to hire a bunch of new staff with slightly different job titles. All while the failing leadership remains unchanged.

Do not accept a job at PDSA. Even if you thrive in your role, you *will* be put at risk of redundancy at some point. You'll see colleagues in tears as they are put at risk, you'll see new people come and go, and eventually it'll be your turn. It's just how PDSA operates.

review_title: Busy pressurised  with inconsistent senior management
job_title: Senior Veterinary Surgeon in London, England
pros: Team work  in the hospitals with a wide range surgical procedures , short days , holidays , lieu time and paid for cpd
cons: Confused middle management  structure with the senior vet surgeon being the fall guy for both the hospital and senior management. Training on how to be a leader is given ( 6 days over 3 years) which is spaced over a long period of time and does not entirely  deal with the realities of running a hospital .Vets until this year have been actively excluded from more senior area manager roles , non vets being preferred with the  inference  and reportage from a senior manager that  vets do not make good leaders .However  non veterinary area managers  do not necessarily offer the support or inherent understanding that a  fellow vet could offer  . Unfortunately however senior vets have not been asked for feedback on this matter . Other grades of staff are well catered for as is reflected in other testimonials . At present the vet is the most expendable and least referred to.

review_title: Beware if you Volunteer, report Gift Aid fraud,  and provide evidence
pros: Very nice customers. Good range of used and new goods in this shop.
cons:
Management covers Gift Aid fraud. My first day working in shop, colleague attached Gift Aid donor label from blank sheet under counter. Added value of item purchased to this tag, and added it to the Gift Aid sales register sheet, to bring charity more money. After reporting this, manager ignored and action continued. Reported to Head Office. Was banned from entering shop after providing evidence!
If you shopped in that shop before reporting fraud, be forewarned, you may not be allowed to enter shop again.
Manager's "pets" can skim all good donations before they can be sold on shop floor (not unusual in charity shop sector).
Also, PDSA did not collect donation that had been planned before I was banned from shop. When I called to re-schedule collection, customer services told me to find another charity to give my donations!

pros: I thoroughly enjoy working for this organisation who have great set of values that are fully aligned to the vision of a lifetime of well-being for every pet. There are opportunities for career progression  within role and lots of opportunities to use transferable skills to apply for roles in other departments. In comparison to other organisations i have worked for they ensure that rather than just get a role filled with some one with the right skills set they also ensure that their behaviours are in line with the values, this really helps support a happy working environment. As with all organisations there are times when difficult decisions have to be made, but i have to say the level of communication around this has been really effective making acceptance of the changes easier.
cons: With being head office based don't get to see the direct impact of the charity first hand on a weekly basis which would be great, although we are encouraged to do hospital visits where possible. There is also lots of communication around case studies of the great work being done that are shared which helps.

review_title: Be wary of the sudden influx of positive reviews, coms have been sent recently to snr managers to add positive reviews
pros: Some great people who really believe in the cause and the sector. Unfortunately, this also enables you to be taken advantage of.
cons:
Combative culture from the top. Blame culture is rife meaning as much time and effort is spent watching your back as it is trying to move the charity forward.

I appreciate money can be tight but this should be taken into consideration on the resourcing. If there are not enough staff, adjust your expectations, instead unrealistic goals are set but you’re still expected to do your day job. This leaves staff stressed and demoralised, worse, it pushes the motivated staff away.

Salaries can be a joke, no transparency, consistency and the current structure rewards you with automatic pay rises for attendance. Performance doesn’t come in to it, meaning the good staff work extremely hard for no reward whilst watching slackers get the same compensation. So..... why bother?

review_title: Potential Employees, please head my warning. DO NOT WORK HERE.
pros: Helping poorly pets in need
cons:
The senior leadership team and the majority of the senior management, have absolutely no clue what they are doing. It is beyond comprehension that they can get into these roles (in some cases for decades) and hold onto them when organisational performance is so poor (barely surviving). If you have the right 'fit' you will get a promotion, but not based on your achievements or lack of them. More that you put up and shut up. 

The sole reason PDSA survive, is due to the kindhearted nature of so many supporters who dearly love animals. They know this fact and they rinse them for every penny they can.

The projects are executed in a frankly abysmal fashion. I can't remember the last project that was actually successful. No innovation, no creativity, nothing but blaming failures and stealing success.

If you can survive this lack of strategic goals, project management, spending out of control, conflicting priorities, unrealistic expectations and deadlines. What will really get you in the end is the culture, for a charity I couldn't quite believe how 'corporate' and deadly it can be. 

This charity has been a sinking ship for years, normally the rats would flee in this situation but instead here they cling on for dear life - and push their unsuspecting victims overboard!

job_title: Head Office Worker in Telford, England
pros: It's a charity. You're part of providing a service to those that need it most.
cons: One of the biggest problems is the lack of leadership and control.  The majority of head office staff do as they please with very little oversight.  Spending money is out of control and its allowed by the most senior staff.  There are some people trying to change the culture but like a very big ship it takes a very long time to turn around.  At times it feels like a company stuck in a time warp.  Lots of resistance to change and too many people that have been there forever who are too comfortable.

pros: I get up in the morning, and look forward to coming in to work. I work with a fabulous team, great work ethics, everyone is driven and passionate about the PDSA. My previous role was unbelievably stressful, pressurised and had such a negative impact on my life. Yet, I have recently (well, nearly a year ago) been succesful in securing my position with the PDSA and I'm so thankful and happy I work here. I have made friends for life within our team, we receive support from each other as and when we need it, we are all equal and to myself personally, I am happy again. We all live and work hard to our values and it's clear to see how driven and passionate we are about the PDSA. Extremely proud to be part  of such a fantastic charity.
cons: I don't feel there are any Cons.

review_title: Excellent career progression gained in such a short space of employment
pros: I've been working with the PDSA for almost 2 years and before that trained with them as a Veterinary Nurse, in my short time back I've met some amazing members of the team and my career has progressed far beyond my expectations in such a short space of time. They give excellent training in management and leadership and I couldn't see myself working for another veterinary organisation for a very long time.
cons: The organisation as a whole is understaffed, this does create a tighter working team as we all understand that we are the core that keeps the doors of the hospital open.

review_title: Enjoying work life in the busy pet hospital!
pros:
I thoroughly enjoy the busy environment of the pet hospital and love that every day is a new challenge. We see a variety of cases and nurses get the chance to utilise their skills. 

We all work as a team throughout the hospital from front of house to the team through the back. 

The role is very much about education and constantly gives you development opportunities.
cons: It is a very busy environment that doesn't suit everybody but you normally go home feeling achieved with how much you have accomplished throughout the day and how many lives you have saved/changed for the better.

review_title: A fantastic organisation to be a part of!
job_title: Voluntary Human Resources Administrative Assistant in Telford, England
pros:
I volunteered in the PDSA's HR department for 5 months and thoroughly enjoyed my time here. 
The Head Office staff were fantastic, and really went out of their way to make me feel welcome. They got me involved with a variety of different tasks, and equipped me with a unique set of skills which definitely helped me in my search for full-time employment. 
It was refreshing to work alongside people who really care about the values of the organisation that they work for. All in all, a brilliant place to work / volunteer!
cons: Personally, I can't think of any.

review_title: Brilliant employer with great promotion and growth structure
pros: PDSA is brilliant for nurses who want to be busy and use their skills to the fullest. Also lots of opportunities for nurses to develop other skills - media and welfare, and also rise up the charity infrastructure and take on more and more responsibility.
cons: The hospitals are in less desirable areas. Short staffed in some places. Uniform is awful.   Treatment options may be limited in some cases.
